A marble bar separates the kitchen from the living room. A trio of stools watch their post dutifully. You walk past them; a blanket of dust coats the black leather seats. You wonder how long its been since Adam fit them.

Adam's fridge droned deep. You peeked over the counter top to see it. Grand metallic doors littered with kitschy magnets. A calendar with a picture of mountainscapes perched near the top. Curious, you amble around the counter and tug open the fridge door. True to your imagination, the fridge is loaded. Everything is bulky.

Double dozen egg cartons, a two-gallon milk jug, tall cans of "Adipop" soda, just to name a few.

Suddenly, your lips feel dry. Adam won't mind if you take a can. Hell he'd encourage it.

You pop the tab, carbonation hisses. A sweet rush of sugar rinses your tongue. You recognized the aftertaste, but welcomed the cool liquid on your sandy tongue. A burp rushes up your throat. You excuse yourself, despite no one being there.

Down a corridor beyond the living-room/kitchen, you discover a flight of ascending stairs on your left and two doors to the right. An open door reveals a soap-white bathroom. You peer inside. Like everything in this world, it resembles a normal bathroom with accommodations for extra-large individuals.

The spacious walk-in shower dry as desert bone. A thin haze of dust lingers in the air. A sudden sneeze parts your lips. The only sign of use is that someone left the toilet seat up.

You step back and check the other door.

Concrete steps descend into dark. You smell the air -- stagnant water, toilet cleaner, and sweat. You enter the basement, one hand firm on the guard rail. A washer and dryer unit huddle beside one another, mounds of laundry surround them. You glance around.

"A weight bench?"

A solid bar rests on metal guards, ready for bench-presses. A rainbow of metal plates scatter the floor around the bench. A half empty water-bottle lays on the floor. Accolades are displayed proudly on a wooden shelf. The largest is a silver trophy.

"Big Dog second place." You read under your breath. Might have to ask Adam about that one later.

You take a seat on the weight bench and look over the other accolades. A picture catches your eye. You lean down at it and squint. It's a picture of two friends against a reddish wall.

You recognize Amy in seconds. A smile on her lips with a pair of red sunglasses perched on her forehead. Her cheeks are a tad leaner, but not much.

It takes you a second to realize that Adam is standing next to her. Seeing her so big beside him only makes him look smaller. He's broad in the shoulders still, and the beginnings of a belly tumble over his boardshorts, but he's unrecognizable all the same. A meaty mitt-like hand is on Adam's hip.

You almost have to double take when it hits you. The wall is actually a whale of a husky that fills out the frame. His bloated face curled into a jovial smile.

"People get that big here?" It would worry you, if it didn't excite the animal part in your brain.

Well and truly shocked, you exit the basement. Questions for Adam brewing in your mind. You debate exploring the rest of the house, when a yawn parts your lips.

Maybe after a break on that plush couch.

~~~

You wake to the sound of electro-pop. The television is on and an advertisement is playing. A doe is strutting on stage with a two liter bottle of pink bubbling soda in her hand and a microphone in the other. Her t-shirt and shorts struggle to contain her. Fat engulfs a thin belt at her waist.

"Adipop helped take my career to the next level." Her exotic voice narrates off screen.

She stops, puts the bottle to her lips, and knocks it back. The pink fluid swirls, her throat flexes. The camera pans over her body. She swells out inch, by inch. Her belt explodes off and her belly cascades in slowmotion. Her thighs explode out of her pants legs. The t-shirt rides up her gut, then her boobs, until it rips in the middle.

All at once it rips off and falls to the floor. A much more revealing outfit in its place. The crowd cheers.

"Adipop: success in excess."

You look at your half empty can of adipop, then at the screen again.

A chortle draws your attention away from the screen. It's Adam leaning over the bar. He's watching you.

"Does that stuff really do that?"

"Nah. It's false advertising really." Adam shrugs. "It helps pack on weight though. A good supplement."

You sit up and stretch. "How long have you been home?"

"Half an hour now. I would've woke you, but you're adorable when you sleep."

"Uh...thanks." You blush.

You swing your legs over the couch and sip your drink.

"Like the house?"

"Yeah. It's nice" You start. "Never expected you to own a weight bench."

"Ah. You saw the gym. It's how I maintain mobility at my size. An old friend taught me some tricks."

Old friend? Speaking of the gym...
132311111.title: You take the time to look around before Adam co...

choices: You ask him more about Woodrow and the Big Dog competition.
Adam explains how your fattening routine's gonna go down.
1323111111.content:
"Hey," you say, " speaking of your gym, what's the Big Dog trophy for?"

         Adam grins. "Well-" he gestures at himself "-I am a dog, and a pretty big one at that. Why, you don't think that deserves a trophy?"

         "In a city where big dogs are easy to come by?" You snort. "You'd have to be a lot bigger than the rest to get a trophy for that." There's a brief pause in the conversation, letting your words sink in. Realization comes just a couple seconds later. "Oh."

         "Bingo." Adam, grin widening, waddles around the bar and plops down next to you. His couch must be pretty heavily reinforced, because it doesn't creak or anything. Must be another necessity of living here.

         "So you... Oh wow." You look Adam over top to bottom. It doesn't take a genius to realize he's big, but big enough to outdo all the other dogs around? Wait, no. His trophy's only for second place. And considering that photo...

         A chuckle pulls you from your train of thought. Adam's not looking at you; he seems to be staring off into the distance. His grin's shrunk down to a smile. "Thought I had first place in the bag..."

         It takes a second, but it's not hard to piece together what he's getting at. "But it went to that big guy, didn't it? The one in the photo, I mean."

         "Hmm?" Adam turns to you. "Oh, you mean good ol' Woodrow?" He leans back and looks up at the ceiling. "Yeah. Real swell fella, that guy. Helped me get some solid footing when I first showed up here. And damn if he doesn't make fat look good!"

         His last comment gets your mind going. Memories of your meeting with Adam earlier today replay in your head, except he's replaced with that gigantic husky-- with Woodrow. "S-Sure wish I could meet him," you mumble, your blush returning full force.

         Adam hums thoughtfully. "Too bad he's a bit out of our reach right now."

         Your ears perk up slightly. "What do you mean?"

         He shrugs. "Exactly what I said. He's living in the high society part of town now. Hard to get in, even for just a visit." A short pause. "Hard to get out, too, according to him."

         Ah, so they keep in contact. There's something reassuring about that. "Have you ever thought about living there?" you ask.

         Adam nods. "Quite a bit, actually. 'Course, there's people down here I don't wanna leave behind either." He turns back to you, his smile gentle and warm. "People like you," he adds with a wink.

         Your heart flutters. "I-I... Uh, gee. Thank you Adam. I'm, uh..." It feels like there's something else you want to say, but you're not sure what. Maybe something to show your appreciation? Yeah, that sounds good. You clear your throat. "I'm sure you'll be to me what Woodrow was, or I guess still is to you."

         His eyes widen for a split second. It's hard to tell, but he might be blushing too. "I'd like that," he says, his voice soft.

------

         It's no surprise Adam's dinner is the size of a feast. Every type of steak, every type of sausage, a wide assortment of potato-based dishes, and giant pitchers of ice-cold water cover the expansive dinner table. That incessant urge to eat has become an unstoppable force driving you to eat everything. And there's so much of it all! If Adam weren't here, you'd probably eat it all yourself!

         The gorging flies by in a juicy, tasty haze. Everything's cooked to perfection, so much so you barely even notice that weird aftertaste. Maybe your table manners look more than a little poor in front of Adam, but you hardly care at the moment. He'd most likely just encourage you to keep it up anyway. So you do.

         It's no doubt been well over an hour since you started by the time you're finished. With a loud belch, you lean back and rub your distended gut. Even the tightness feels pretty good. It's still too early to say, but this whole getting fat thing doesn't seem all that--

         A louder, huger belch shakes the table. You turn to Adam. He's doing the same thing as you. His belly is pressed up against the side of the table. You both belch again, at the same time. He turns to you, and the two of you exchange grins.
1323111111.title: Finally, Some Questions are Answered

choices: Later, Adam invites you to watch some TV with him.
That night, you have trouble sleeping.
You manage to fall asleep later. Naturally, you have dreams...
13231111111.content:
The two of you spend some time in silence. You nurse your distended belly as gingerly as possible. Anything more than a light touch hurts.

         Occasionally, you glance over at Adam to see him being a lot more grabby with his own. Despite eating far more, his belly's still malleable enough to grope and knead like a pile of clay. You linger a few moments longer with each glance. By the fourth time you look at him, you can't tear your eyes away. He's like a master sculptor, carefully molding his next masterpiece.

         He catches you staring and flashes a grin. "You'd be surprised how fun this is."

         You blush for what feels like the millionth time today. "It looks fun. I mean, it looks like you're having fun," you stammer.

         Adam just nods. "It's gonna take some time before you're totally comfy with all this fat business, huh?" he says.

         You grunt some vaguely affirmative noise. "You'd think that wouldn't be a problem, but... I dunno, you think it might be something leftover from my old life?"

         "Probably," he says with a shrug. "Not like we'll ever know one way or another."

         "Right..." You lean back and stare at the ceiling. Hey, he's got some pretty nice tiles. Not enough to take your mind off things, though. Maybe a change of topic will help.

         "So, hey," you say, readjusting yourself as you turn back to Adam, "if you don't mind my asking, what exactly happened at that Big Dog competition?"

         There was a frown on his face, but he brightens up at your question. "Oh, I don't mind at all! It's nothing super exciting, though. Just to give ya fair warning."

         You smile back. "I don't mind."

         "Well in that case, I guess I better tell ya 'bout the competition itself first. See, it's not just a contest to see who's the fattest dog. If anything, it's sorta like--" he gestures at the air around him "--well, no, it is a modeling competition. Just one made specially for fat dogs."

         Your head slightly tilts to one side. "Why specifically dogs?"

         Adam throws his arms out, making them jiggle. "Hell if I know. It's like that for every species. Heard the reasoning's 'species-specific standards' or something like that. Never made sense to me."

         You feel inclined to agree, though that might just be the way he's explaining it. "So it's supposed to decide the Mr. Adipose of dogs, or something?"

         "Best way to put it, really. It's not just about how big you are--" he pats his gut "--but how good you look."

         "And for you to win second place..." You give a low whistle. "You must've been quite a hit."

         "Still am, thank you very much," Adam says, his wide grin betraying the mock offense in his tone. "But yeah, I've gotten a lot of compliments in my time. Maybe a few too many for my own good."

         You raise an eyebrow. "Huh?"

         A hint of embarrassment slips into Adam's expression. "Remember how I said I thought I'd win first place?"

         Your jaw drops a little before the realization fully hits you. Received too many compliments, assumed he was a shoe-in for first... Not hard to figure out where he's going with this. "Ah," is all you can think to say.

         Adam's grin is more wry now. "Yup. Pretty sure that's why Woodrow joined in the first place, mostly cuz he told me so himself," he adds with a chuckle.

         Your brow furrows. Something about the phrasing seems off to you. "Wait," you say, "joined in the first place... So he only joined to beat you? He wouldn't have otherwise?"

         "Yeah, he's not one for the spotlight. Never got a straight answer why." Adam looks down and lightly shakes his belly. "Kind of ironic when you think about it."

         "He doesn't like attention?" you ask. "Then why'd he get so fat when he lives in a city like this?"

         Adam pats his hips. "Prob'ly the same reason I did."

         "Which is...?"

         He shakes his head. "If you're anything like me--and I get the feeling you are--you'll understand after a hundred or so pounds."

         A hundred pounds... Maybe not too much compared to everyone else in the city, but to your thin little self, gaining that much would be close to doubling your body weight. Your throat's suddenly feeling a little dry, your heart rate's picking up. It doesn't feel like fear, though. More like...

         Ah, there's that increasingly familiar heat in your cheeks. It's only going to get even more familiar in the coming days, no doubt. You avert your gaze to the direction opposite Adam. All you see is a window with the curtains shut. They look pretty thick, perhaps excessively so. Then again, isn't that the point?

         "But anyway," Adam says, "back to Woodrow: he's a pretty sweet guy when he's not being a tough lover."

         Your head whips around to face him. "Wha-?!"

         Adam's face screws up like he's holding back a laugh. "Not like that, ya silly pervert! We never did anything like that!" There's a pause. His expression softens, then he sighs. "Not even once." It's hard to tell, but it almost sounds like there's a tinge of disappointment in that last statement.

         Regardless, you feel relieved. Doesn't make you blush any less, though. "Oh," you say quite lamely, "uh, sorry."

         "Don't be," he says, waving a hand dismissively. "All I'm saying is he's a nice guy, but he's not against taking you down a peg if necessary. Anyway, it's getting late. We should clean up."

         As he gets up, you move to do the same. A sharp pain in your gut forces you to yelp. You groan, your hands hovering over the dome of your belly, too scared to touch it. How'd you forget about this?!

         "Oh boy," Adam says, stopping mid-reach for your plates. "Want me to get you some pills for that?"

         "Please," you hiss.

         Adam then sets his stack of plates down and hurries off somewhere. While the pain is at the forefront of your mind, a part of you still takes a second to appreciate how attentive he's being. You can't help but smile at that.
13231111111.title: Just a Bit More Detail

choices: I wouldn't mind staying out here with you until I crash.
Maybe the guest room isn't a bad idea, it's been a long day.
Actually, can I come to bed with you?
132311111111.content:
You tilt your head back and down three hot pink pills. A few moments pass, then a soft bubbling sensation warms your stomach and numbs the pain. It lulls you into a daze. Plates clink and water rattles against the metallic basin of the kitchen sink. You crack an eye open and you peek over your shoulder.

Adam's broad figure obscures most of the sink. His sleeves are rolled up past his elbows, his thick forearms dark and slick. The dishwasher is loaded with neat rows of plates and bowls; what doesn't fit there is stacked on the counter. He towels his arms off then raises them above his head. A deep yawn rumbles the air.

"Oof, not used to cleaning up for two." He says. The hound wobbles over to you and leans over the now spotless table. Adam reaches over and pats your shoulder. "Those pills are good stuff right?"

"My insides feel like a bubble bath." You stretch your legs forward. Tension eases out of your lower back. You stare at the pile of clean dishes. A sigh ekes between your lips. "Jeez sorry for not pitching in."

"Consider it a welcome to Zaftig City gift from yours truly." Adam says. "Better enjoy it, tomorrow you're doing all the dishes."

You both share a chuckle as you scratch the slight curve of your middle. "I'll do all the dishes you throw at me if I get to eat like this every day."

"Careful. You end up eating like me and you'll be in here for hours."

"We'll do it together at that point." You smile up at him. His ponderous frame casts a wide shadow over you. You glance at the sink, and your medicine dazed mind lets your thought slip. "We might need a bigger kitchen by then."

"We?" You almost hear the smile in Adam's voice. "How long do you plan on staying here?"

"Oh I-I didn't..."

"Relax. I don't mind the company." Adam says. He clears his throat and rubs his thumbs together. "Speaking of company. You wanna go hang out in the living room? We can veg out to some late night TV and eat snacks."

"Jeez I don't think I could stomach another bite." You drum your fingers against your taut belly.

"Grab some just in case. Appetites have a habit of returning after those pills wear off." Adam says.

You scoot away from the kitchen table and attempt to stand. Adam helps steady you as you find your balance. To call the feeling 'weightless' would be inaccurate. The food in your gut pulls you forward. It just doesn't hurt any more. You follow Adam to the pantry and grab your choice of snackfoods.

Adam pulls open the fridge and hauls a case of soda from a shelf. He catches you staring and shrugs. "In my experience, one can isn't enough."

"Two or three isn't either, apparently." You playfully stick your tongue out at him.

"You laugh, but you'll thank me later."

Soon you're both seated with your legs spread to accommodate your bellies. Adam pops the top of a can and sifts through channel after channel. He sips his soda, stopping every few channels to gauge his interest in the program.

He stops at an infomercial of all things. Adam stifles a belch and points his noise at the screen. A fur so massive you can barely tell he's a feline is reclined in a mattress. He's naked, his groin covered only by the flesh apron of his stomach. A sea of chins wobbles as he speaks. You manage to regain your thoughts on his last sentence. "-that's until I got a Mobi-cart."

The scene switches to a vibrant colored scene of many furs of different sizes stationed around the park. The spokesfur now center frame in a scooter.

Adam clears his throat. "I'm probably the last person who should reprimand, but we're going to try and avoid getting you one of those. Just...trust me."

You stare at the smiling actors puttering around, enjoying nature without all the fuss of actual movement. You can't help but ask: "why? Seems to be the natural order of things here. Bigger is better and we can't carry all that weight forever."

"I'd agree if I never met someone like Woodrow. I don't know where we came from, you know before the city, but you know it in your gut that people that look like me weren't the norm." Adam's nose twitches thoughtfully. "I think bodies couldn't handle it there. Here it seems...different. Like somehow we're built for bigness now."

You think you understand. Every fiber of your brain knows the feast from earlier should have burst you open. Yet here you are eyeballing a bag of chips with ravenous intent.

"It's easy to get lost in it. Get fat fast formulas that blow you up in a few months time. Heck, I wager sometime in the near future someone your size can look like Mr. Mobicart there in a few days. People love that here. The immediate satisfaction."

"But you lose mobility if you grow too fast."

"Exactly. Our bodies want to get used to it now, but if you go too fast it never gets a chance to catch up." Adam nods. "Woodrow can move around just as well as you and me. Well, so long as he has the space. He out grew his apartment."

"Wow." Just trying to imagine outgrowing your current get-up is difficult. Outgrowing your living space even more so.

"But enough of me rambling. Just know I won't ever mess you up and leave you."

He flips the channel again. This time to a sitcom. It stars a big fat family, except the teenage son who is thin. No doubt to rebel. A novelty from, well, wherever you're from. Here it could only be the norm.

You pull open your chips and start to snack. Between hokey laugh tracks that drink up the fat dad's bad jokes and crunchy snack food, it's hard to pay attention. You glance at Adam off and on and wonder if he does the same to you.

He catches you one time. "Thirsty?" He wiggles his can.

"Uh. Yeah." You look away and lick your teeth of salt.

Adam plops a chilled soda on the coffee table. You sip it to deflect his attention. Hoping he's paid no mind to your awkward voyeurism.

"Goodness you're about as bad as me when you first got here." Adam laughs aloud.

"Wha-"

"Listen. We've just met, but I know how you're feeling right now." Adam reaches his arm across the back of the sofa. His furry arm brushes against the back of your head. "Big first day in a world you literally woke up in. You feel differently about things here than you would other wise."

You go silent and clasp your fingers together.

"I think you're an okay guy so far. Hard to tell on the first day, but you remind me so much of a fresh faced me, it's like I've known you forever."

The weight of Adam's arm rests on your shoulders. He brushes his finger through the fur on your cheek. You quiver at the sudden touch.

"You're that trusting of a total stranger?" You say.

"That's the fun thing about this city. We're all strangers from a world we don't remember. For all we know, we could have met on the street in a different life."

You lean your face against his palm. "Good to know that the Big Dog runner-up doesn't mind a twig."

"That's going to change soon." Adam pokes the light curve of your belly.

His arm tugs at you gently. You scoot close to him and lay your head against his chest. His moob feels plush and warm against your cheek. You reach over and pinch a handful of his love handle. You feel his body shiver.

"Been wanting to do that all day." You mumble. He squeezes your hip with his fat paw. You lay your arm across his stomach and embrace him as best you can. "I hope I look as good as you when I'm this big."

"You'll look like you." Adam scratches behind your ear and hugs you back.

You're enveloped in warmth and soft chub. Deep within you feel a hint of firmness. You close your eyes, then let yourself relax against him.

You hear a distant laugh track while fantasies play out in your head. You imagine yourself enveloping Adam in your own sea of girth. He's struggling to wrap his arms around you. Heat rises to your face. You want to hold on forever.

Adam holds you in his arms your until exhaustion finally sets in. A yawn contorts your maw.

"Guess it's time for bed." Adam releases the hug. "The guest room is all set up for you upstairs."

You ponder the option a moment before you decide:
132311111111.title: Quality Time

choices: Adam has the day off, so he's staying at home with you.
He has to work today, so you're by yourself.
He has work, and wants you to come with him.
1323111111112.content:
"Yeah," you mumble as you get up off the couch. As much as you'd rather stay with Adam, it's only a matter of time before you fall asleep on him, and it wouldn't be fair to make him carry you upstairs. He's done plenty for you as is. "See you in the morning, or...?"

         "Of course you'll see me; it's kinda hard not to." Adam flashes a smirk. "Anyway, guest room's on the far end of the left side."

         "Okay." You pause to let out another yawn. "G'night."

         "G'night. Hope you sleep well."

         "Yeah, me too," you mumble, mostly to yourself. There's a lot to take in right now. Way too much, especially in your sleepy state. And the last thing you need is nightmares.

         Past the living room kitchen, through the corridor, up the stairs and down the left and sure enough, there's the guest room. The first thing you notice is the big bed on the far side. No doubt meant for people closer to Adam's size. Hopefully you won't end up literally lost in the sheets come morning.

         You give the rest of the room a quick once-over. Sizable overall, of course. You can't make out much thanks to the darkness, but what you can see tells you it's a pretty plain room overall. The bed and dresser and desk and such look nice, but more in a generic kind of way than anything. There seem to be a couple paintings as well, but you're just too tired to try and make them out in the dark.

         So you just plod over to the bed and slip under the cover and sheets. Ah, nice and soft. So is the pillow. Your worries melt away as a soothing warmth envelops you. With your biggest yawn yet, you close your eyes and sigh in contentment.

         Yeah, you'll get used to this no problem.

------

         Waking up is a much better experience this time around. No blinding light, and no headache either. And it certainly helps that you're not naked in some park again. But that goes without saying.

         You can safely say your sleep was restful, for the most part. No especially bad dreams, at least. There was one part where that silver fox lady, Beth, had you strapped to a chair and was about to feed you hyper-fattening goop. Thankfully, Adam bailed you out just in time. The rest was just a collection of goings-on based off what you currently know about the city; people rapidly fattening up from massive meals, meeting hyper-obese Mobi-cart riders, a much fatter you taking part in a modeling competition called Foxy Fatties, Adam personally feeding you and rubbing your growing fat all the while... That last one went on noticeably longer than the others.

         You shake your head and give the bed a once over. Brown cover with white sheets. Not bad. They decently fit with the rest of the house. Same for the dark green blinds on the window. Seems Adam put some genuine thought into his interior design. Well, that would make sense; he is the manager for a clothing store, after all. Good understanding of color schemes comes with the territory.

         A dresser sits to your immediate left. Dark brown with a nice wooden finish. To your right is a work desk of similar appearance. Its wide surface is bare and lightly coated with dust. The accompanying chair bares the same wood finish as the other furniture, and is padded with soft, light green cushioning. It's pretty big as well. Two of you could fit on it no problem.

         On the far wall are the two paintings you noticed last night. The one directly across from you depicts a hill overlooking an expansive grassland. A lovely piece, though now it has you wondering how much greenery is in the city. Or what lies beyond it for that matter.

         Those musings are cut short once you focus on the other painting. It's a full length portrait of a grey wolf man clad in an blue army uniform. A general or some other high-ranking officer, judging by the decorations he's wearing. He carries a confident demeanor about him. A grin graces his muzzle. One hand rests on his hip while the other holds a shotgun, with the weapon's barrel resting on his shoulder. But his most striking feature has to be his overall figure. He's definitely got some serious muscle, going by the curvature of his limbs, but his torso is unmistakably fat. No way a bulbous gut like his wouldn't fill out his lap. And those pectoral bulges are definitely moobs. You have to hand it to the artist, even from a distance the detail put into the painting really pops out. The shading, the coloring, the texture... This has to be a master's work. The wolf looks like he could jump out and give you a big bear hug any second now.

         That idea sounds a lot more appealing than you'd openly admit.

         A loud growl disrupts your thoughts. You look down and lightly pat your stomach. It growls again. That incessant desire to eat is stronger than ever. In one fluid motion, you pull the covers off and hop off the bed. Hints of a tantalizing scent tickle your nose. Breakfast. You grin and move to leave the room, only to pause when you notice a certain pressure a little ways below your empty stomach.

         Right. Better take care of that first.

------

         Thankfully there's a bathroom one door down from the guest room, so you don't have to go far to do your business. And man, does Adam have an eye for quality toilet paper! This stuff is soft! The hand soap feels a bit strange for some reason, though. Maybe it has to do with your fur? It does still feel "wrong."

         Eh, you'll adapt. Right now, you need to take care of your poor stomach; it's been begging for food all the while.

         The intoxicating smell of breakfast leads you down to the kitchen. A sizable sprawl--consisting of every hot breakfast food imaginable--covers the table. Adam (who's wearing a tight-fitting white shirt and dark grey boxers) sets down a plate of breakfast burritos, looks up at you and smiles. "Morning, sleepyhead," he says. "How're you feeling?"

         "Pretty good, all things considered," you reply, eyes darting between him and the feast. "Where'd you get the time to make all this?"

         Adam chuckles. "When you eat like me, you learn how to make big meals in a hurry. Plus it's actually kinda late in the morning. Quarter after ten, in fact. Been working on all this since eight."

         You give a low whistle. "You sure know how to treat yourself."

         "Hey, it's for you too. Gotta start your first proper day in Zaftig on the right foot. Just remember it's your turn to do the dishes."

13231111111122.content:
After feasting on breakfast for what felt like hours, you were once again stuffed to the brim. Your belly was just as expanded and engorged as it was last night. Or maybe it was slightly larger? At the other end of the table was Adam. You noticed that he held back a bit during the meal. Not like that makes much of a difference; he still probably ended up eating more than you.

"So," you say while leaning back in your chair and running a hand along your swollen gut, "what's the plan for today?"

"Well, I need to head off to work in a few minutes." said Adam. Your face must have drooped noticeably. "Don't worry, I won't be gone that long. Besides, there's plenty of stuff for you to do around here. I've got all the television channels, a bunch of video games..."

"A fully-stocked kitchen..." you finished.

Adam smiled as he got up from the table. "Yep, and a fully stocked kitchen. So feel free to make yourself something if you're feeling peckish later. But for now, I need to leave otherwise I'll be late for work, then they'll fire me, and then I'll have no way to cover all the food you...I mean we, have been eating." He walked over to the front door and grabbed his keys off the nearby table.

"Hey Adam," you yell from the kitchen table.

"Yeah?"

BURP You belch loudly from the kitchen. That caused Adam to chuckle to himself. "And don't forgot: You're doing the dishes. You promise!" Adam left the house. After a minute or two of recovering from your meal, you waddle back upstairs with your swollen belly, make your way into your guest room, and land on the bed for a nap.

***

Several hours later, you wake up. Once more, you belly is somewhat swollen but you are not feeling as full as did after breakfast. You scratch your gut from under your blanket. "What to do? What to do?" you ask yourself. "Eat," you reply to yourself. After all, Adam is essentially paying for you to fatten up, so it's only fair to keep eating.

Back in the kitchen, you roam around looking for something to refill your belly with. Opening the freezer compartment of the refrigerator, you immediately notice a full carton of ice cream. Birthday cake flavored. Your favorite.

"Happy Birthday to me..." you say to yourself, pulling the carton out and placing it on the counter. You begin searching the kitchen for a bowl when you realize that won't be necessary. Rather, you find a spoon, rip off the top, and eat a large spoonful. Your tail slowly wags as the ice cream coats your tongue.

You pick up the container and carry it with you. It's only been a day since you came here, so you figured that you might want to look around Adam's house again to get acquainted with the place.

After wandering around for a quarter of an hour, you find yourself back in the room with Adam's weight set. You sit your foxy butt down on the weight bench as you admire all of Adam's trophies again. As you shovel more ice cream into your mouth, you eye catches that photo again. Adam, Amy, and the unknown massive husky. You walk over to the photo encase in a frame with glass and marvel at the husky. How did he get so big? Can he even more around? How does he know Adam? Adam warned you about about amateurs and jerks who might blow you up to immobility. Was this husky such a victim?

As you examine the photo, you catch your reflection in the glass protecting it. Adjusting yourself a bit, you move the reflection of your face on the glass over the face of the husky. That forces a giggle out of you. You puff up your cheeks and now the image of your bloated face on the glass covers the pudgy jowls of the husky. Another laugh comes from you.

But then you examine the photo again. Your face on that massive husky's body. You can't help but imagine yourself in his place. Instead of a husky, a red fox is there blown up to massive proportions. Your own meaty paw around Adam's hip, and you start to think about what a life you two would have with yourself that fat. Adam, the bulky German Shepard, and you, the ultra-massive fox. Adam would have to spend nearly all day cooking for you to make sure that you don't start to slim down. He'll have to help you bath since you won't be able to clean all your fat rolls. And stairs? You'll have to move your bedroom downstairs. Scratch that, we'll have to move our bedroom downstairs. And speaking of bedroom...

As your imagination continues, you don't notice that you're scrapping the bottom of the ice cream container. Thinking about getting as big as that husky got you so excited you aren't realizing that you finished your sweet treat until you are pouring the last drops of ice cream into your mouth. You notice that your belly feels just as full as it did after breakfast. But there is an immense urge inside of you to keep eating. Eat and keep growing. As big as Adam. As big as the husky. No, bigger than the husky.

"No," you think to yourself, "Adam agreed to help me put on some weight. I don't know how he'll feel about dealing with a half-ton fox...But, there is a lot of food in his kitchen..."

What do you do?

13231111111123.content:
You waste no time in loading your plate of breakfast goodies. A mountain of fluffy white scrambled eggs with the faintest hints of cheddar. A squat tower of flapjacks, plush, warm, and tender. Breakfast sausage plumper than Adam's fingers, drizzling delectable juices that puddle on your tray-like plate.

Your stomach mewls, your fingers twitch, unsure where to start. You work left to right. At first trying to savor each bite. The eggs slide down your throat and bring their warmth to your gut. They flavor sticks to your teeth, lingering on your tongue. You lick your lips clean and jab the pancakes with your fork. Though, something's missing.

"Adam could you," a sudden burp interrupts you, that sickly sweet aftertaste heavy on your breath, "could you pass the syrup?"

He grunts an affirmative between his own mouthful of food. He suckles the syrup from his fingertips and wipes his hand on a napkin before passing you the pitcher of amber colored delight. The handle is warm to the touch and steam trickles off the surface. You slather the pancakes, the syrup that gleams like liquid jewelry.

It's tempting to forgo the fork and use your hands, but you aren't that much of a pig. You cut large segments with the flat of your fork, spear a handful, and jam them into your waiting maw. They practically melt in your mouth. Your stomach churns, the chunks of pancake rest heavily in your belly.

You and Adam say nothing amid the gorging. He looks up at you from time to time and you smile at him with cheeks stuffed full of food. There are only the sounds of muffled breathing, cutlery clicking on dishes, the satisfied grunt that follows a delicious bite. The breakfast your host graciously prepared dwindles each passing minute. Between the experienced veteran and the ravenous greenhorn, there is little left in your wake. Your stomach churns, the skin around your middle taut and bloated. You lean back in your seat, idly massaging the aching distension above your lap.

There is a single slice of quiche on the far end of the table. Yellow and speckled with spices. Your mind says no, you're full, your stomach begs to test its limits. You lean forward and gasp. The aching pain in your middle pins you back.

Adam dabs food debris from his chin, eyes on the distant quiche. "You want that?" He rests his hands on the peak of his belly. The chair creaks beneath him. His ill-fitting white t-shirt rode the curve of his belly. Exposing the furry flesh for all to see. He tugs it down, but his gut forces it back up. He gives the beast a gentle pat.

"Maybe," a hiccup catches you off guard, you cover your mouth. Breakfast sits in your gut like a ball of lead. "Or maybe not, you can have it."

Adam shrugs and shimmies back a bit. The chair grinding the floor, the sound echoes off the ceiling. He wobbles to his feet, his plump biceps flex as he steadies himself on the table. He grabs the entire dish with the quiche and waddles to you. A grin lights up his muzzle. It's a hungry face, though not for food. He sets the plate in front of you.

"I'm going to pop," you whine, your ears flatten.

"I wouldn't let that happen, trust me," he grabs a fork and carves bite, "besides, I've got belly to spare. You need all the help you can get."

It hovers in front of your face a moment. Every waking thought in your mind screams for you to stop. Your mouth didn't get the memo. The hinges on your maw loosen, your tongue unfolds. A bed that awaits the morsel.

Adam pops the fork in your mouth and you muzzle clamps shut. An alien sensation fills your being. There's a pounding warmth in your chest. Your legs feel limp. His meaty mit-like paws reach under your shirt, experienced fingers knead the tension out of your gut. The warmth spreads up your spine now, your neck relaxes and your mouth opens to accept the next bite. You don't even register the fullness anymore, it's less about eating now. Bite after bite, you guarantee that Adam will have no leftovers.

Metal fork meets empty plate, a soft ding sound tickles your ears. He's panting, his ears pert and his tongue lolling out. Adam clears his throat. "Knew you had it in you."

You hum softly. The reality of your decision weighing heavily on your middle. You groan and hug yourself. "It's not going to be in me for long."

Adam grimaces and waddles to the nearby cabinet where a familiar bottle of pink pills awaits. He tugs the seat of his boxers free of his rear and taps the pills back into your hand. "I promise someday you'll have enough room to handle any meal without really worrying about using these," he fills you a glass of water at the sink.

You force the pills down, praying it all stays down. The pain fades and your face relaxes. Adam stands beside you a moment, gently rubbing your back. "Sorry, shouldn't have pushed you."

"I could've said no," you smile up at him, "and you have to go all in to get big, right?"

"Something like that." Adam's cheeks dimple. The corners of his maw turned upward. "So, last night I got to thinking, it's gotta be boring being stuck in my house all day long."

"Oh," you shrug, "I'll find ways to entertain myself." The refrigerators hum becomes more apparent.

"You could come to work with me," Adam says, a little faster than he might have intended, he puts a hand on his hip and leans on the table. His tail swishing rapidly.

You idly massage your stomach. "Won't, you know," an uneasy feeling wells in your chest, "'others' find me?"

"I'll make sure they don't do anything." Adam stares at you with the biggest puppy eyes he could muster. The lightning blue pigment in his eyes glimmer. He licks his lips and clasps his hands.

"Okay, okay, I'll tag along," you sigh, gripping the table's edge and forcing yourself to your feet.

"Perfect!" Adam helps you to your feet. "Now speaking of which, I need to slip into something a little more presentable," he shakes his belly for emphasis.

You nod, the pills are really kicking in now. Adam's jiggling middle seems to move in slow motion. It's hard to turn away. "You do that."

Adam pats your back. "Alright, I'll be back in a bit." Adam waddles from the kitchen. His tree-trunk thick legs brush one another, the curve of his rear shifts with his steps.

"Hate to see you go, love to watch you leave," you mumble to yourself, trying to remember where you heard such a thing. You stretch your arms over your head and yawn. The spread of spent dishes ever imposing. Time to make good on your offer.

132311111111231.content:
Adams car, or more accurately, truck, is far more spacious than Amy's vehicle. The kettle seat affords you tons of room, though just plenty enough for Adam. He's dressed in a similar outfit from the previous day. Now doubt the store's uniform. The pastel blue polo clings to his frame like a thin sheet. Sparse bits of fur peek where the fabric runs thinnest. He looks down at the shirt. "It's an older one, my bigger ones are all in the wash." He shrugs.

You lean your head against the cool glass of his car window. The morning crowd is already bustling with life. Hefty furs in motorized carts take up the largest sections of the sidewalk while others struggle to stay in the lines. Adam's car passes the park you 'arrived' from. A tall metal sign with tin floral sculptures decorating it reads: "Adventus Memorial Park."

A foggy memory of a life long lost tickles your brain. Adventus. Adventus. Advent. You remember the chill of winter air and the nip of snow on your...skin? It hurts your head to think of it. A calendar with compartments comes to mind, a day of the week with little candies in each.

"You alright?" Adam's voice reaches in and tears you from the scant memory.

"Yeah, yeah," you rub your temples, "do you guys celebrate anything during the winter here?"

"Of course! We've got this thing called the Saturnalia Festival. Really you could say the festival is like the last three months of the year, but it's a big deal round these parts," Adam chuckles, "y ou think we all gorge now, wait until the season swings in, hoo boy."

"Saturnalia," you let the word sink into your brain. No, that wasn't the name you were looking for. "So, it's like a feasting holiday."

"Winter was the time when our ancestors would pack on a bunch of weight to fight the cold, so I guess they made a festival of it. These days, no one starves come winter, though."

You drum your fingers on the armrest. Claw tips accidentally stick the leather fabric. You grimace and hope Adam didn't notice. Adam hooks a corner and pulls into a parking garage a few blocks from his store. A camera scans a sticker on the windshield of his car. Green light flashes, a bar lifts, and Adam is permitted parking. He scours the vast expanse of blacktop in search of a spot. Finally, he parks in a 'reserved' parking space. The trucks AC rumbles to a halt as Adam pulls the keys from the ignition.

"Reserved parking? Didn't realize you were that important."

"All employees at the 'Strip' are allowed reserved parking," Adam says, he points the sticker on his windshield, "some of the stores here don't have a lot of space for parking."

"Yours does, though." You cock your head.

"I have to get my daily walk in somehow." Adam presses a button on his key fob and the truck chirped in response. The headlights flickered.

"Cardio and lifting," you shake your head, "and how do you stay so big again?"

"I eat." Adam pats his gut.

He wobbles at a decent pace through the dark parking lot. Flickering fluorescent lights buzz and tingle your ear drums. You scratch your cheek. The pair of you stops at lift enclosed in glass. It's far wider than any elevator you've ever seen and looks more apt to carry cargo than people. Adam's ponderous hips bump you as he steps inside, reminding you the necessity of larger than life elevators. He presses a button on a panel and the elevator whirs to life. The glass walls flicker.

Fish float around you like you're surrounded by an aquarium. A deep voice speaks: "the sea calls to you."

Soft sitar music plays and the images of fish flicker. Furs of various sizes are raiding a buffet of seafood dishes. An obese otter dressed in a toga rolls on screen in a chariot. "Poseidon's Bounty awaits."

The advertisement flickers off and you rub your eyes. "That place any good?"

"Never been, maybe I can take you," Adam smirks.

He waddles off the elevator onto the street level. Where once you were a car seat spectator, you're now in the fray. Wide hipped furs hog the sidewalks and you're stuck behind Adam as he carves you a path. You feel insignificant, cradling your beginner's belly in your oversized clothes.

Despite his ponderous size, Adam outpaces you with his gait. It starts to dawn on you that the only thing really holding him back is the bulk, not the weight. No one can walk all that great when your thighs constantly touch.

Certain members of the crowd look at you. Some seem to understand the situation. You're the new guy and Adam's 'adopted' you. Others laugh and whisper.

They're not the ones you're worried about. You keep your eyes peeled for a silver fox with green eyes. No doubt massively obese, maybe even Adam sized. You wonder if she drives a Mobi-cart.

After a nerve-wracking few minutes, you finally reach "Urban Trends." The sign for the store is styled after pop-art, with the letters in gritty stenciled text. Top forty hits play on the speakers above. You listen for lyrics you recognize to no avail.

"So, no one thinks it's weird that I'll be your little shadow today?"

"New arrivals need help, people understand that," Adam holds the door open for you, "and I volunteered to help you. It's kind of like an unwritten code."

Amy stands at the cash register, inspecting her claws. The store is mostly vacant, save for a few plump teenagers carrying armfuls of clothes into a fitting room. A beleaguered fitting room attendant leans against the wall, looking ready to quit his life at any moment. You stick close to Adam's hip.

"There's the big boss," Amy looks up from her claws and beams at the two of you, "and the new guy actually came back outside again. I'm impressed."

"You keep an eye out, alright," Adam leaned close to Amy, "Beth should know better, but people like her aren't right in the head."

"Will do," the lioness looks down at you, "you two look like you're getting along."

"We'll make an honest citizen out of him yet," Adam rubs your shoulder, "he's got the appetite for it, that's for sure."

Amy leans over the counter, her bulbous cleavage bunched by her shirt. "So what's the plan for today?"

"He's going to stick with me while I work, maybe pitch in and help a bit," Adam waddled around the counter toward a backroom, "and if you're up for it, we could try a restaurant tonight. It'll be like old times. Minus 'you-know-who' of course."

Amy offers a knowing nod. "You sure the newby'll be safe?"

"Between the two of us, he's got nothing to be afraid of." Adam stretched his arms over his head, his polo became untucked and he mumbled curses beneath his breath. He reached over the girth of his gut and tucked the offending bunch of fabric.

He gestures for you to follow him to the back, only for you to notice a plume of fabric is untucked at his rear. The waist of his gray boxers peeks above his snug khakis. You reach over and tuck it for him. He yelps.

"Missed a spot."

Amy bursts into laughter and Adam's face turns bashful. The two of you make your way to the back of the store. Maybe going out wasn't such a bad idea.

---

As you tiptoe down the hallway, you can feel your belly wobble a bit from your steps. It's still firm with food, but it also has a bit more jiggle to it than before. "Uh, yeah," you mummble.

You realize what he means as your tail droops down to cover up your bare bum a little bit. "Uh, I guess so," you say. Your face is still red.

Adam laughed again. "Well, as much as I like seeing a little bloated fox dance around in my bathroom, I need to pee."

"Uh, yeah. Yeah. And I guess I have to go back to bed." You walk towards the bathroom doorway. Adam turns to his side to let you slide by. You side-shuffle through the door when both of your bellies brush up against each other. You walk back down the hallway to your guest room and you swear that you can feel Adam's eyes watching you. Your foxtail lifts up slightly again, exposing a bit more of your skinny butt. "Just in case he is watching" you think to yourself as you go back into your bedroom and shut the door behind you.

"So," you say, panting your hands on your belly. "Is this how it's going go down? Is this how I'm going to get big?"

Adam yawned and leaned back, letting his shirt ride up on his belly a couple of inches. "Well, that depends on you." He tugged his shirt back down over his swollen gut. "That's one way of doing it. Overeat, don't exercise too much, repeat. And considering how much you just ate, keep it up and you'll be a pudgy fox in no time."

"Just pudgy?" you say as you give your full belly a shake.

"Like I said, that depends on you. Taking it slow, you can put on as much as you feel comfortable with though it'll take some time. Pudgy fox, rotund fox, freakishly fat fox, it's up to you."

You laugh at the last suggestion. "I don't know if I want to get 'freakishly' fat."

"Fantastically fat?" asked Adam. "Formidably fat? Foundation-shaking fat?"

You playfully stick out your tongue at Adam.

Adam laughs back. "Well, there is another way besides the traditional way of getting fat..." You tilt your head to the side inquisitively. "You see, there's this guy I know. He's named Stephen. He works at this research facility right at the edge of town. The Subcutaneous Society or Institute or something like that. I forgot. Anyways, he has approached me and some of the other guys who usually show up at the Big Dog competition with a offer. Apparently, the Institute Stephen works for developed a way to put on massive amounts of weight in a fairly short period of time."

"Did you take him up on that offer?"

"No. Remember, being a Big Dog requires having a nice combination of beef and flab. The Institute is more interested in the later. Stephen assured me that he could bulk me up, but it would be all fat. That's why myself and none of the other guys agreed to be one of his test subjects. You're not even allowed to exercise while on the program. Except for some leg exercises. Squats and stuff. They don't want your leg muscle to atrophy so much."

"So, how it is that they suppose they can fatten someone up?"

"Science," replied Adam. "Really, I'm not sure. But they can do it with something called the Functional Adipose Tissue Agitator Sucrose Supplement."

You think for a moment about that. "...FATASS?"

"Clever, isn't it? It's part of an inside joke in the lap, according to Stephen. Apparently, their first subject, this kangaroo guy, came out of the program looking like he was smuggling two beach balls full of pudding in the back of his sweatpants. You should have seen it. It was amazing; Stephen showed me a few photos."

You chuckle at the thought. How would a kangaroo with a rump that big be able to waddle around? Where would his tail go? If you went to the Institute, is that how would you end up? Your hips are already slightly on the wide side. Would you even be able to get out of the building?

"Hey, you still there?" Adam asked. You have been staring off into space for the past minute thinking about that FATASS kangaroo. "What do you think?"

132313.content:
"Wait, what do you mean that I'm going to get fat 'sooner or later'?" you asked Adam.

"There's something about this city that just makes people, well, blow up. Maybe it's the food, maybe it's the culture. I dunno. But what I do know is what I've seen. Every once in a while, a skinny fur like you pops up in town. They say that they're going to stay trim and fit. But it's always those ones who blow up the biggest. A couple of years ago, I met this guy about your size, maybe a little taller. He was so put off by the sheer fatness of everyone who lives here. The guy kept going on about how he'll go to the gym everyday and watch what he eat and all. Well, last time I saw him, he pushing well over six hundred pounds."

"Okay, so some people lose control and get fat. But what do you mean that someone might try and blow me up?" you retorted.

"Some people here are okay with skinny furs. Others are not. And the ones who aren't tend to be a little...aggressive when it comes to making skinny furs bigger," Adam said. "And, well, I should know, I-"

"Adam! Where are you? The cash register is malfunctioning again!" shouted a voice from across the store.

"Crap, not again," the German Shepherd said. "Give me some time to fix this." He pointed down a hallway. "Until then, go down the hall, and go through the second door on the left. In there, we keep all the clothes we can't sell. Irregular fits, minors tears, you know. Go in there and find something to wear. I'm sure nobody will miss anything that you take."

"ADAM?!?" the voice shrilled.

"Okay, gotta go! I'll join you when I'm done!" The bulky pup turned away from you and sped-walked away.

Not wanting any of the other employees to see you in the nude, you quickly ran down the hall and into the door Adam indicated. The room was very dark. You rubbed your hand against the wall until you found a light switch. You then saw that the room was filles with boxes of unsellable clothes, and you went to work finding something to cover you up.

After some time, you managed to find something to wear. You pulled out from one of the boxes a pair of black sweatpants, one leg significantly longer than the other. But they were designed for someone much taller and wider than you, so you rolled up the legs to make sure they wouldn't drag on the ground. You tightened the sweatpants' drawstring as much as you could which luckily made the waist small enough so they hung albeit loosely from your hips. To cover your torso, you found a simple white tank that flowed almost down to your knees. You didn't look exactly fashionable, but you weren't naked anymore and that's what mattered.

Sitting on one of the boxes of clothes, you thought about your situation. Adam was pretty adamant that, like it or not, you'll end up fat in this city. But you had your doubts. A city that made its citizens obese sounded absurd, even if some maniacs were running around fattening furs. And although Adam made it sound as if he was being kind in offering to help plump you up, who said that you wanted to be fat? And how fat was fat enough to be "safe" here? And what if Adam was actually one of those psychos fattening people against their will?

Adam walked through the door around ten minutes later. "Sorry about that," he apologized. "There's a stupid button on the register and if you hit it the only way to fix it is to go through this whole messy process. But I fixed everything." The German Shepherd eyed your new outfit. "Going pretty... causal, huh?"

"I'm no longer stark naked, so these clothes seem to serve their purpose," you replied.

"True, true. So, have you thought about what I said."

"Yeah, and still have lots of questions," you said.

"I can see that. Go ahead."
132313.title: Still unsure

choices: "What if I don't want to get just fat? Can I put on some muscle too?"
"What if I don't want to get fat? Is there some other way?"
1323131.content:
"How do I know that I can trust you?" you asked. "How do I know you're really looking out for me, a stranger, and aren't actually planning something evil?"

"Well," began Adam. "I think you can trust me because...I want to make sure nothing happens to you like what happened to me."

"...explain."

"Okay, storytime then." the German Shepherd started. "I moved to this city a few years ago hoping to start a new career since I had to retire as a body builder."

"Wait, you used to be a body builder?" you asked astonished.

"Yep! 'Adonis Adam', then used to call me!" He then lifted up his arm and flexed. You could make out a fair bit of muscle hidden underneath layers of adipose. "300 pounds of solid muscle! 7% body fat! Unfortunately, I slipped while lifting and got a nasty injury. So no more body building for me."

"So then what? You moved here and discovered a love for cheesecake or something?" you jested.

Adam laughed. "They make some pretty good cheesecake here! I'll be sure to make you try a slice or three. No, when I got here I landed a job at a research facility. But not as a researcher. More as a test subject. The doctors wooed me, saying my physique was perfect for their lastest experiments. They signed me for a sweetheart deal. I really should have been more careful. I still beat myself up over how stupid I was."

"Then what happened?" you asked.

"On the first day of the trials, one of those damn researchers drugged me. I woke up tied to a bed hooked up to a bunch of machines. They had this hose secured to my mouth and they forced this sickly sweet slurry down my throat. Five times, everyday. They had kidnapped me for months. Each day was a cycle of chugging down that stuff and fading into unconsciousnes."

"What were they experimenting on you for?" you asked.

"I'm not sure. But whatever the doctors were filling me up with blew me up bad. When the investigators busted into the institution to arrest everyone, I was getting close to 800 pounds."

"Oh my God!" you exclaimed. "They fattened you up that big?!"

"Yep. What's worse is that since I was tied down 24/7, all my muscles atrophed. I was pretty much a helpless blob. Nearly a half ton of blubber. I was all but rolled out of there."

"But you aren't now. So what did you do?"

"Well," said Adam. "I went on a bit of a diet. The first couple of hundred pounds were easy to shed. Without that sludge being pumped into me everyday, those pounds just melted off. And it wasn't like I could waddle down the street and pig out on burgers or anything. My leg muscles had wasted away so much that I need help getting around. When I got to 600, I was able to start doing some lifting at the gym. It helped me build my leg and arm muscles back up. Eventually, I got down to 475 but I just could lose anymore weight. The food here is just too damn good, I guess. That, and I got used to the size. A good mix of beef and blubber, I think. I have put on a little more muscle. It helps carry the weight around. I think these days I'm hovering around 530."

"Wow..." you said. "I'm really sorry that happened to you. It must have been traumatic."

"It's in the past now," Adam said dismissively. "But that's why I think you can trust me. I know what some of the crazies here can do. And I wouldn't inflict what I went through on anyone else. I consider it a kind of promise to myself. So while knowing my history may not make you wholely trust me, I sure hope that it shows that I have nothing but good intentions."

Having listened to Adam's story, you got the sense that he seems genuine about wanting to help you. So while you got the sense that you can't quite entirely put your full trust in him yet, you started feeling a bit more safer around him.

"Okay, okay," you said. "I can see why would want to help someone in a situation like mine. But I still have one more question."

Adam nodded. "Okay. Shoot."

Just stand right in front of me." You stepped up to Adam, who towered over you. You saw as one of his paws yanked up his shirt, exposing his hefty, brown-furred belly. "Let me see your paw." You cautiously raised a paw up, and Adam took it in his. He placed your paw on his belly; it sunk a couple of inches. "How does it feel?"

"It feels...soft, like a marshmallow. And really warm..." you replied. You brought up your other paw and placed it on Adam's belly. You then began moving your paws in small circular motions.

"Liking it?" Adam asked. You said nothing but your cheeks burned brightly. "You also know what's great about being a quarter-ton fur? I just take up so much space now..." Adam reached for your paws and dragged them over to his fleshy flanks. Due to the size of the dog's gargantuan giant, this yanked you forward and soon you body was hugging tightly against Adam's pudgy gut. "Hey look! I'm so big that you can't fit your arms around me!" You ignored him as you were too busy nuzzling your face into his pillow-like abdomen.

133.content:
The whine of fluorescent bulbs sounds magnified ten fold to your aching ears.An unfamiliar sensation tingles and itches upon your face. A strong, anti-septic smell clouds your sense of smell. You look around yourself, you recognize the room. Or you think you do. You feel like you remember dreaming it. It's a hospital lobby. Empty.

A thick chill races up and down your spine. This cold is very real. It might help to find something to cover up with. You take two deep breaths, then tuck your hands into your armpits for warmth. Your soaked fur leaves a translucent trail wherever you walk, you take a mental note to inform the staff. If you find anyone that is. You approach the main desk, only to discover a seat with an abandoned sweater hanging off the back.

"Is anybody there?" You say between bouts of chattering teeth.

No response. The rumble of the rain deafening in the silence of the hospital. With nothing to lose, nor anyone to tell you no, you walk around the counter and scoop up the sweater. The fabric swallows your thin arms and dangles low to the ground. The owner of the sweater must be at least three times your size.

An ID badge dangling from the collar confirms your theory. A positively cherubic fox smiles for the camera. His plump cheeks dimple with the curve of his lips. His loose jowls caught in mid jiggle.

"Anthony Gaines? Security?" You read the black text beneath his picture. "Like this guy is stopping anyone."

Desperate for warmth, you throw the billowing sweater over your naked body. The thick fabric dangles past your groin and rubs against your knees while you stand. The faint smell of sweat and grease emanates from the fiber. You grimace a little, better this than nothing you suppose.

One cursory glance at his desk and you realize the great big security guard left his sandwich half-eaten. Not to judge, but you figure a guy of his stature never left a bite behind. Not unless something urgent happened. You gulp and jiggle the mouse at the computer terminal at his desk.

The screen saver leaves to reveal he started a game of mine-sweeper. He started it four hours ago, with the clock still ticking. You minimize the window to find nothing else interesting on his desktop. A sigh escapes your lips while you try and click around for something helpful.

Hospital Intranet? That piques your interest. You double click it to reveal his e-mail minimized in the task tray.

"Tonygaines@zcgh.net: strange happenings."

You click further.

"Fellow security staff,

Anyone else hear the stuff going on in the East Wing at night? I thought it was the graveyard shift moving cadavers at first, but the morgue downstairs stayed untouched when I checked later. I might just be getting paranoid, but someone's sneaking in after hours.

"Re:strange happenings.

IDK Tony, I don't hear it on my shift. Could just be the pipes. This place is old as sin after all."

You scroll through message after message, much of it the same. Tony seems convinced of something though. You check the garbage bin of his e-mail, it hasn't been emptied that day. The e-mail is addressed to him, from himself, and deleted. Curious, you click it.

"Fat dope,

Keep this East Wing business to yourself or there are going to be consequences

- J"

A loud thunder clap shakes the air outside, and causes the lights to flicker, then go out. The computer terminal shuts down and leaves you in the dark. Thankfully, your natural night vision begins to set in. You can see, but not well enough to navigate your unfamiliar surroundings.

You search the desk and find a penlight. Once more, better this than nothing. You click the light on and make your way to the front door. Much to your surprise, a police officer awaits you. Much like Tony, he appears to be thrice your own size..

"Hey! What're you doing here?"

Shocked, you freeze in place. You've never been one to break the law. Yet it seemed all to convenient that someone show up when you learn a little more about this Tony fellow. Rather than risk meeting whatever fate he did, you bolt in the opposite direction.

The officer attempts to follow you, only to slide in the water you tracked in.

He falls to the ground and cries out in pain. He lays there and groans for a moment. This is your chance.

You dash down the hall. The baggy sweater catching your feet ever so often. You stumble, but manage to keep some balance. You check door after door in an attempt to hide. Your paws fumbling over the knobs in the dark. Finally one door works. You throw open the door and run inside.

Darkness stares back at you from the depths of a stairwell. Heavy panting and lumbering footsteps echo down the hall. Someone's on your trail. Cautious, but deliberate, you move into the darkness. You hunt each step with your feet.

A nagging thought came to mind. How far will this lead you? Some part of you is convinced it might lead out. The same part that drew you to the hospital for shelter, perhaps. The scent of formaldehyde stings your nose the further you walk along. You point the penlight ahead and notice a metal door.

The morgue is just ahead. You gulp and peek over your shoulder. The chances of you making it in one piece might very well be in the hands of the dead.

You open the metal door and lock it behind you. That might keep some pursuers at bay. At least for awhile. You pace around the chilled metal room. Rows and rows of the dead rested before you. You focus the light on a stainless steel table. Judging by the instruments and tools surrounding it, you figure someone used it not too long ago.

A few discarded syringes dotted an empty dish. An empty IV pouch sat beside the table. Odd, in that the dead had little use for life preserving measures. Someone operated on a living patient, you are certain. A pile of clothing is folded with care on the floor by the table.

Upon closer inspection they appear similar in size to the sweater now draped upon your body. What exactly happened to this Tony fellow? Perhaps you did not want to know. You take a few steps back, when a bright flashlight beam lit up your eyes.

"Don't move."

The cop from earlier somehow got through the lock. You look in his paw and notice a key ring dangling from his wrist. Who gave him that, you wonder? You hold your hands up and sigh. Your first day you remember in the city, and it's going conclude in jail.

"You're lucky I found you first. There are others trying to find you." The cop held ups his own hands. "I thought I told you to get out of the city first, why did you come back to the hospital."

"I-I don't remember you talking to me. I don't even remember you."

"Christ, not even my face?"

"Nothing. I don't even remember my own name."

"Perhaps it's best we speak in private. Just come with me and I promise I will get you out of here in one piece."

You've entered a small hut, probably a ranger station of sorts used by the individuals who keep watch ob the over-large park in the middle of the city. It's small and sparsely furnished with a desk, a couple chairs, a cot, some filing cabinets, a poster board, and so on. Basically what everyone might expect to find in a typical small office. Outside the storm seems as terrible as every and the few trees that can be seen through the window sway heavilly under the wind and the rain.

You try to regain your composure and try to get your head together but that nearly goes out the window when you feel a hand thump down on your shoulder.

You turn, heart pounding, mind filled with cliches from slasher movies, but the figure is dressed in tan pants and a green shirt overlaid with an orange vest and topped with a wide-brimmed green hat. It takes you another moment to notice the figure is a rather jovial looking gray furred wolf. The wolf was quite stout, looking almost as wide as he was tall, as his belly, which was like a great ball, was barely contained by his uniform and only lightly squeezed by his belt.

"Sorry to frighten you like that," he smiles with a very faint southern accent, "But I don't get many guests in my office, especially not on a day like this. And especially especially not naked as the day they were born."

At this you look down and blush as you realize you are indeed completely naked, though the fur of your privates seems to hide them well, you still duck behind one of the filing cabinets out of embarrassment as the wold just laughs.

"Aw, no need to be so jumpy," he smiles, "I'm not one to judge. Besides, you aren't the first one to show up completely naked and looking confused and lost."

This particularly gets your attention, as it seems others might had found this place much the same way you did.

"Here," the wolf pulls out a towel from a nearby closet, "You look like you could use a warm shower, follow me."

The wolf leads you through the door in the back of the office into a small bedroom, though the bed is little more than a double mattress on some blocks. Through another door is a nice bathroom which he ushers you into, "get nice and warm and clean. We'll talk once you're feeling better."

Eagerly you hop in, glad to feel the warmth leach the chill from your bones. You spend maybe a bit longer in the shower than you mean to, glad for the heat, before finally, reluctantly, getting out and toweling off. When you get out he has a nice hot meal waiting, mostly park foods of hot dogs, burgers, popcorn, pretzels, soda and a nice big hot fudge Sunday.

"The concession stand is right next door," the wolf smiled, "I was able to make a quick dash from here to there and back with some food for you. Don't worry, it's all free."

As you eat the wolf began explaining that there had been a odd occurrence over the years of beings showing up in the park, naked and with no memory of how they got there. nobody had seen how they arrived, and there had been no records of them in the town before. it was as though they just appeared there for some reason, and yet no one had ever seen it happen.

"Sometimes it gets busy too," the wolf chuckled, "Had at least half a dozen appear in near the exact same spot on the same day just hours apart. Took us a week to get them sorted out."

As the ranger finished you couldn't help but yawn, having been more tired than you thought. With a smile the ranger lets you snuggle into his bed for the time being. "I'm sorry, you yawn as you drift off, "I don't even know your name..."

The wolf smiles, "It's Rodger." Though even as he says it you drift off to sleep.


Hours later you yawn and stretch, memories slowly coming back about that had happened as you slowly get up and spy a stack of clothes in a nearby chair. As you pull them on you glance in a nearby mirror and are surprised to see your formerly lithe body now sported a small belly. True, you had pigged out a bit before you fell asleep, but it hadn't felt like that much at the time. It wasn't a large belly though, barely sticking out four inches from flat. Cute and shapely though far from a burden. Though it is a little unsettling as you slip on the remaining clothes that they all seem a tad large even with your slightly rounder middle.

Soon Rodger comes back and smiles, "Good to see those clothes fit, I honestly had to guess your size and I wasn't sure if I got it right. They're lost and found items, and don't worry, they've been missing for a while so it's unlikely anyone is going to come for them."

Idly you wonder for a moment what events could have caused one or more individuals to loose their shirt and/or pants in the park, but shake it off quickly not needing the imagery in your head.

The storm seems to have stopped and so you feel you're ready to face the day. Before you leave Rodger gives you his number in case anything happens and you need his help as well as some numbers of folks who might give you some help also. Once more thanking the wolf for his generous hospitality you step boldly out of the cabin into the bright sunshine of a new day full of promise.

Now, where to go....
